dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Four hundred thousand daily passengers on those new German buses in Almaty—that's a massive upgrade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Four hundred thousand daily passengers on those new German buses in Almaty-that's a massive upgrade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinese buses can barely cope with the 600,000 daily passenger traffic, BAKAD is struggling, LRT tender lasting already fourth years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the LRT project was finished in just a year, which is uh, pretty impressive timing for infrastructure like that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the L R T project was finished in just a year, which is uh, pretty impressive timing for infrastructure like that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinese buses can barely cope with the 600,000 daily passenger traffic, BAKAD is struggling, LRT tender lasting already fourth years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and then there's the metro expansion plans—they're aiming for a full 30-kilometer ring with 15 stations eventually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and then there's the metro expansion plans-they're aiming for a full thirty-kilometer ring with fifteen stations eventually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The total length of Almaty metro ring will be 50 km and 28 stations, including 13 underground and 15 ground stations along railway tracks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But it sounds like there's some friction, like KTZ not planning to extend single-track sections, which could really complicate things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it sounds like there's some friction, like K T Z not planning to extend single-track sections, which could really complicate things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: KTZ has plans to extend single-track section from Almaty-1 to Almaty-2 with an additional double-track line insert.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and they're even talking about decommissioning the section between Almaty-1 and Almaty-2 stations, which seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and they're even talking about decommissioning the section between Almatyminus one and Almatyminus two stations, which seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the past, a radical closing scenario of Almaty-2 railway station in the city center and use of remaining Almaty-1 station has been discussed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the issue of integrating railway and metro lines—it's not common practice in Europe or Japan, so that's a bold move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the issue of integrating railway and metro lines-it's not common practice in Europe or Japan, so that's a bold move.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Combination of railway and metro lines is usual good practice in Europe, Japan, Russia and China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, the delay on stations like Kalkaman and Western station near Altyn Orda market is gonna leave some suburbs isolated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, the delay on stations like Kalkaman and Western station near Altyn Orda market is gonna leave some suburbs isolated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is tough for areas like Burunday and the Industrial zone—they could end up feeling like ghost towns if the metro doesn't reach them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is tough for areas like Burunday and the Industrial zone-they could end up feeling like ghost towns if the metro doesn't reach them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the comparison to Moscow is interesting—their ring line carries 200,000 passengers a day, while Almaty's current half-ring already matches that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the comparison to Moscow is interesting-their ring line carries two hundred thousand passengers a day, while Almaty's current half-ring already matches that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An interesting fact, the Moscow Metro Ring Line of 12 stations, 19 km long, has traffic of 540 thousand passengers per day. Almaty half-ring metro of 9 stations, 11 km long carries in average 40 thousand passengers per day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But without cooperation between Akimat and KTZ, it seems like this metro ring vision might stay just a vision.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But without cooperation between Akimat and K T Z, it seems like this metro ring vision might stay just a vision.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Technical implementation of metro ringing is only possible by close cooperation between Akimat and KTZ.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And those ground-based stations like Baum Grove might never even get built, or worse, get demolished later.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And those ground-based stations like Baum Grove might never even get built, or worse, get demolished later.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a shame, 'cause the potential is clearly there—500,000 passengers a day on that ring would handle most of the city's public transport needs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a shame, 'cause the potential is clearly there-five hundred thousand passengers a day on that ring would handle most of the city's public transport needs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The passenger traffic of the ring circled metro will be about 300 thousand passengers per day, or 50% of the total public passenger traffic of Almaty.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But until they sort out the funding and coordination, it feels like Almaty's transit future is still up in the air.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But until they sort out the funding and coordination, it feels like Almaty's transit future is still up in the air.

artist_script:
HostA: Four hundred thousand daily passengers on those new German buses in Almaty—that’s a massive upgrade.
HostB: Yeah, and the LRT project was finished in just a year, which is uh, pretty impressive timing for infrastructure like that.
HostA: Right, and then there’s the metro expansion plans—they’re aiming for a full 30-kilometer ring with 15 stations eventually.
HostB: But it sounds like there’s some friction, like KTZ not planning to extend single-track sections, which could really complicate things.
HostA: Exactly, and they’re even talking about decommissioning the section between Almaty-1 and Almaty-2 stations, which seems counterintuitive.
HostB: And then there’s the issue of integrating railway and metro lines—it’s not common practice in Europe or Japan, so that’s a bold move.
HostA: Plus, the delay on stations like Kalkaman and Western station near Altyn Orda market is gonna leave some suburbs isolated.
HostB: Which is tough for areas like Burunday and the Industrial zone—they could end up feeling like ghost towns if the metro doesn’t reach them.
HostA: And the comparison to Moscow is interesting—their ring line carries 200,000 passengers a day, while Almaty’s current half-ring already matches that.
HostB: But without cooperation between Akimat and KTZ, it seems like this metro ring vision might stay just a vision.
HostA: And those ground-based stations like Baum Grove might never even get built, or worse, get demolished later.
HostB: It’s a shame, ‘cause the potential is clearly there—500,000 passengers a day on that ring would handle most of the city’s public transport needs.
HostA: But until they sort out the funding and coordination, it feels like Almaty’s transit future is still up in the air.
